gen.metadata.title: Dual-band bidirectional circularly polarized microstrip antenna for CubeSat system
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and demonstrate a novel dual-band bidirectional microstrip antenna with identical right-handed circular polarization for CubeSat applications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve dual-band operation at 1.575 GHz and 2.230 GHz (p. 1); Ensure bidirectional radiation with identical right-handed circular polarization (p. 1); Verify the performance through simulation and measurement (p. 3)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for a low-cost, compact, and lightweight dual-band bidirectional circularly polarized microstrip antenna for CubeSat systems (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a single-feeding network and single-layer substrate be used to achieve dual-band bidirectional circular polarization? (p. 1); What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna at 1.575 GHz and 2.230 GHz? (p. 3)
esp.domain_results.axial_ratio_bandwidth: 15 MHz for -z direction and 17 MHz for +z direction (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.bandwidth: 85 MHz for 1.575 GHz and 85 MHz for 2.230 GHz (p. 3)
esp.domain_results.cross_polarization_le: 16 dB for -z-axis at 1.575 GHz and 26 dB for +z-axis at 2.230 GHz (p. 3)
esp.domain_results.gain: 0 dBic for forward radiation at 2.228 GHz (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Bidirectional broadside radiation patterns toward -z-axis at 1.575 GHz and +z-axis at 2.230 GHz (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Dual-band bidirectional circularly polarized microstrip antenna (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: FR4 substrate (εr = 4.2, tan δ = 0.018, h = 1.6 mm) (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Single-feeding network with a quarter-wave impedance transformer matching circuit (p. 2)

gen.metadata.title: Design of a wideband circularly polarized 2 x 2 array with shorted annular patches at X-band on a CubeSat
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a single layer wideband circularly polarized 2 x 2 microstrip array at X-band frequencies for a 1U CubeSat (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Model the 2 x 2 array on a 1U CubeSat (p. 1); Compare the performance of the 2 x 2 array to a single element microstrip antenna (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigation of the array's performance in real-world satellite communication scenarios (p. 2)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Further testing and validation of the design through measured results (p. 2)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for a wideband circularly polarized antenna for radio communication systems on nano-satellites, specifically 1U CubeSats (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a single layer 2 x 2 microstrip array using shorted annular patch elements be designed for X-band frequencies? (p. 1); What are the performance benefits of the 2 x 2 array compared to a single element microstrip antenna? (p. 1)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The 2 x 2 array outperforms a single element microstrip antenna in terms of wideband circular polarization (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: 2 x 2 microstrip array with shorted annular patches (p. 1)

gen.metadata.title: High-Gain Compact Circularly Polarized X-Band Superstrate Antenna for CubeSat Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and fabricate a high-gain, compact, and lightweight circularly polarized X-band superstrate antenna for CubeSat applications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Optimize the size and arrangement of passive elements in the superstrate layer to maximize gain and bandwidth (p. 2); Not mentioned; Ensure the antenna is suitable for CubeSat missions by maintaining a compact size and low weight (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Not mentioned; Investigate the performance of the antenna in different CubeSat configurations and environments (p. 4)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Not mentioned; Use the proposed antenna design in CubeSat missions for improved communication performance (p. 4)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for high gain, wideband, and compact antennas for CubeSat X-band communication systems (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What is the optimal design for a compact, lightweight, and high-performance X-band antenna for CubeSats? (p. 1); How can the gain and bandwidth of a microstrip antenna be improved for CubeSat applications? (p. 1); Not mentioned
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: HFSS FEM method and QNM package (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms other designs in S11 bandwidth, SLL, gain, cross-polarization level, and size (p. 4)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_siz: 6.84% of a 1U CubeSat's top face (10 × 10 cm²) (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: High-gain circularly polarized X-band superstrate antenna (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers RT 5880 (εr = 2.1, tan δ = 0.001, h = 1.5 mm) (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: CP single-feed hexagonal-shaped patch with a slot (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.superstrate: A: 10 mm, B: 9 mm, C: 8 mm, D: 7 mm, E: 6 mm (p. 3)

gen.metadata.title: Low-Profile Circularly-Polarized Isoflux Beam Antenna Array Based on Annular Aperture Elements for CubeSat Earth Coverage Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and demonstrate a low-profile 5 GHz sequential rotation-fed antenna array with isoflux radiation pattern for CubeSat earth coverage applications (p. 10)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve a low profile and light weight design (p. 10); Optimize the radiator and feeding network parameters to achieve the desired performance (p. 6); Deduce an overall reflection coefficient to characterize impedance matching (p. 2); Design and fabricate a prototype operating at C band (5 GHz) (p. 1); Develop a radiation pattern modelling method for the array (p. 2); Not mentioned; Meet the frequency, footprint size, profile, polarization, AR, gain, and efficiency requirements (p. 6); Ensure good electrical performance (p. 10); Compare performance with existing designs (p. 10)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Not mentioned; Investigate the impact of different substrate materials and thicknesses (p. 7); Explore the use of the antenna array in different CubeSat missions (p. 7); Explore the application of the design method to other frequency bands (p. 10)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Not mentioned; Use the proposed design for CubeSat earth coverage applications (p. 10); Further optimization of the feeding network to improve performance (p. 7)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Small satellites, particularly CubeSats, require antennas with stringent indicators such as low mass, low profile, small size, and mechanical robustness. Current antenna designs for earth coverage beams are often bulky and heavy, limiting their application in CubeSats (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a low-profile antenna array be designed for CubeSat applications? (p. 10); How can the antenna array meet the requirements for a 400 km-orbit CubeSat with a circular earth coverage area of 250 km²? (p. 6); What are the optimal parameters for achieving the required radiation pattern and performance metrics? (p. 6); How can a low-profile, light-weight, and easy-to-integrate antenna array be designed for CubeSat earth coverage applications? (p. 1); Not mentioned; What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna array compared to existing designs? (p. 10)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: R&S ZVA67 VNA and MVG Starlab antenna pattern measurement system (p. 8)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Radiation pattern modelling method, overall reflection coefficient, hybrid synthesis program (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The proposed array features a low profile, light weight, and ease-of-integration, making it suitable for CubeSat applications (p. 1)
esp.domain_results.gain: 4.7 dBic at θ = ±35°, 2.2 dBic at θ = 0° (p. 6)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: CP isoflux beam antenna array based on sequential rotation-fed annular aperture elements (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Two annular apertures: inner aperture (circular patch antenna element) and outer aperture (eight rationally arranged PIFA elements) (p. 10)

gen.metadata.title: A 3-D metal printed folded-shorted patch array with an integrated feeding circuit offering dual-band circularly polarised radiation for cubesat applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To investigate the use of 3-D metal printing technology for the fabrication of a miniaturised CP antenna for dual-band communications in CubeSats (p. 4)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Measure the performance metrics including gain, bandwidth, and efficiency (p. 4); Optimize the dimensions of the radiating slots for dual-band operation (p. 2); Achieve consistent fabrication quality of FSP elements (p. 2); Integrate a wideband feeding network for CP functionality (p. 2); Design and fabricate a 2 by 2 array of FSP elements (p. 4)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigation of the antenna's performance in space environments (p. 5); Investigate the impact of environmental conditions on the performance of 3-D printed FSP antennas (p. 3); Development of multi-band and multi-functional antenna designs (p. 5)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use 3-D metal printing technology for consistent fabrication of FSP elements (p. 2); Further optimization of the feeding circuit for improved performance (p. 5); Optimize radiating slot dimensions for dual-band operation (p. 2); Exploration of different array configurations for versatility (p. 5)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Challenges in achieving consistent fabrication quality and dual-band operation for compact antennas in CubeSats (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can 3-D metal printing technology improve the fabrication consistency and dual-band operation of folded-shorted patch (FSP) antennas for CubeSats? (p. 1); What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna design compared to existing designs? (p. 4); How can 3-D metal printing technology be used to fabricate a miniaturised CP antenna for CubeSats? (p. 4); What are the performance metrics of the proposed 3-D printed FSP antenna array? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: HFSS FEM method and QNM package (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms other designs in terms of size, dual-band functionality, and efficiency (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.cross_polarization_le: More than 20 dB below the main beam maximum at broadside (p. 3)
esp.domain_results.gain: 2.32 dBic at 1.2 GHz and 1.84 dBic at 2.45 GHz (p. 5)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_siz: 0.4 × 0.4 × 0.056 λ³₀ (where λ₀ is the free space wavelength at 1.2 GHz) (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Miniaturised CP antenna using 3-D metal printing (p. 4)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Five-port feeding network with 180° and 90° couplers (p. 2)

gen.metadata.title: A New Patch Antenna for CubeSat: Dual feed, L/S dual-band stacked, and circularly polarized
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a compact Yagi antenna with an integrated balun for CubeSat applications, achieving adaptive frequency operation and high gain at different frequency bands (p. 4)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve high gain at different frequency bands (p. 9); Maintain a compact volume and low profile (p. 9); Achieve high gains at different angles and frequency bands (p. 4); Ensure low manufacturing cost (p. 9); Develop a Yagi antenna design that can operate at L-band and S-band by adjusting the angle between the antenna and the satellite (p. 4); Not mentioned; Design a mechanically adjustable antenna to achieve three functional states at different operating frequencies (p. 1); Evaluate the performance metrics such as gain, bandwidth, and radiation patterns (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigation of other frequency bands and antenna configurations (p. 9); Not mentioned; Further testing and optimization of the antenna design for different CubeSat configurations (p. 1); Investigate more elaborate deployment mechanisms for multi-angle operations (p. 4)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Not mentioned; CubeSat designers can choose from three popular frequencies through a simple angle configuration (p. 1); Use the proposed antenna design for CubeSat missions to achieve adaptive frequency operation and high gain (p. 9); Further testing in different environments to validate performance (p. 9)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for a compact, low-cost, and high-performance antenna for CubeSat applications, particularly addressing the limitations between antenna size and performance (p. 4)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What is the impact of adaptive frequency operation on the performance of the antenna? (p. 4); What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna design? (p. 1); How can a printed Yagi antenna with an integrated balun be designed to operate at multiple frequencies in the L-band and S-band? (p. 1); Not mentioned; How can the antenna size be minimized while maintaining high performance for CubeSat applications? (p. 4); How can a patch antenna be designed to achieve high gain and multi-frequency operation for CubeSat applications? (p. 9)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Compared with other printed Yagi antenna designs, e.g., those listed in Table 1, our proposed antenna provides the highest gain at angle A = 10°, that is 8.167 dBi in measurement, however, its bandwidth is narrower. Reference [17] shows higher value of gain than other designs, but the size of this antenna is 43 mm longer than our proposed structure. Thus, besides the adaptive frequency operation, the proposed antenna with tapered balun provides good gain performance in terms of higher gain, and a low reflection coefficient based on the feasible size for CubeSat applications (p. 7)
esp.domain_results.gain: 8.167 dBi at 2.4 GHz, 5.278 dBi at 1.3 GHz, 6.120 dBi at 3 GHz (p. 1)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Directional behavior on both planes when A = 90° and 50°. When A = 10°, the measured radiation pattern is closer to unidirectional on θ = 90° and obvious directional on φ = 90° (p. 6)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Dual-feed, dual-band, circularly polarized patch antenna (p. 9)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: FR4 substrate, with a dielectric constant of 4.4 and a thickness of 0.6 mm (p. 5)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Tapered balun integrated with the printed antenna (p. 4)
esp.technical_specifications.frequency_b: L-band (1.3–1.4 GHz) and S-band (2.38–2.54 GHz and 2.82–3.08 GHz) (p. 4)

gen.metadata.title: High-gain patch antenna for cubesat-based automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast application
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a miniaturized high-gain antenna suitable for hosting into a cubesat for ADS-B operation (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve a compact size and low-profile structure (p. 1); Ensure sufficient bandwidth and good gain over the operating band for ADS-B receiver (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate further improvements in radiation efficiency at higher frequencies (p. 3)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the proposed antenna design for cubesat-based ADS-B applications (p. 3)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Designing a compact and high-gain antenna for cubesat-based ADS-B operation is challenging (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a compact and high-gain antenna be designed for cubesat-based ADS-B operation? (p. 1)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The proposed antenna has a compact size and high gain, making it suitable for cubesat-based ADS-B operation (p. 3)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Directional with a −3 dB aperture (beamwidth) of about 85-90° (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_siz: 0.29 λ0 × 0.29λ0 × 0.03λ0 in electrical length at 1.090 GHz (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Stacked-patch antenna with slots and reflectors (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Probe feed at location 18 mm from the center in the x-direction (p. 2)

gen.metadata.title: Design, Fabrication and Measurements of an X-Band Cross-Patch Antenna with Metasurface for Advanced LEO CubeSat Missions
gen.objectives.main_objective: To develop a miniaturized and optimized metasurface antenna for CubeSats that meets the requirements of minimal aerodynamic drag, extended mission duration, and efficient power consumption (p. 10)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Design and optimize a planar crossed dipole antenna using HFSS FEM method and QNM package (p. 2); Ensure the antenna does not require deployment mechanisms after launch (p. 10); Improve antenna performance using metasurface to increase CubeSat lifetime and data throughput (p. 2); Evaluate the fabricated antenna prototypes through measurements and compare them to simulation results (p. 2); Evaluate the antenna's performance in terms of gain, bandwidth, and radiation pattern (p. 5); Optimize the metasurface unit cell to enhance antenna performance (p. 10); Optimize the antenna design to minimize size and power consumption while maximizing performance (p. 5); Design a cross-patch antenna with a metasurface to achieve high gain and wide bandwidth (p. 10)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the performance of the metasurface antenna in different environmental conditions (p. 8); Explore the application of the antenna design in other frequency bands (p. 10); Investigate the performance of the antenna in different orbital conditions and with varying CubeSat configurations (p. 2); Develop multilayer Fabry-Perot antennas to achieve even higher gains (p. 10); Explore the use of advanced materials to further enhance antenna performance (p. 8)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Conduct further testing to optimize the design for different CubeSat sizes and missions (p. 8); Integrate the proposed antenna design into 1U CubeSat missions to enhance communication and mission longevity (p. 1); Integrate the developed antenna design into CubeSat missions to enhance communication capabilities (p. 10); Integrate the metasurface antenna design into CubeSat missions to improve communication efficiency (p. 8); Optimize the metasurface unit cell for further performance improvements (p. 10)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for a compact, lightweight, and efficient antenna design for CubeSats to extend mission duration and improve data reception periods while maintaining low power consumption (p. 10)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What are the key performance metrics that can be achieved with the new antenna design? (p. 10); What are the performance improvements of the metasurface antenna compared to traditional designs? (p. 5); How can the antenna design be optimized to meet the geometrical, mechanical, and electrical requirements of CubeSats? (p. 5); What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna design, and how do they compare to existing designs? (p. 2); How can a cross-patch antenna with metasurface be designed to occupy less than 8% of a 1U CubeSat's top face while maintaining high performance? (p. 2); How can the antenna design be optimized to meet the size and performance requirements of CubeSats? (p. 10)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: HFSS FEM method and QNM package (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The proposed antenna design outperforms other designs in terms of gain, bandwidth, and size (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_siz: 6.84% of a 1U CubeSat's top face (10 × 10 cm²) (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers RT 5880 (εr = 2.1, tan δ = 0.001, h = 1.5 mm) (p. 2)

gen.metadata.title: High-Gain Pixel Patch Antenna Array for Miniature Wireless Communications and IoT Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To investigate pixel antenna arrays for wireless communication and IoT systems, focusing on design, analysis, and comparison with traditional designs (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve a 75% reduction in patch design area and a 90% reduction in full design area (p. 14); Design and analyze pixel patch antennas for 5G and CubeSat applications (p. 1); Compare the performance of traditional and proposed pixel patch antennas (p. 1); Evaluate the performance of the proposed pixel antenna array in terms of gain and radiation pattern (p. 14)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigation of the proposed design in real-world 5G and CubeSat applications (p. 6); Investigate the performance of the proposed design in different environments and applications (p. 14)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the proposed pixel antenna design in small space devices and miniaturized systems (p. 14); Further testing and optimization of the proposed design for different frequency bands (p. 6)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for small, high-gain, and efficient antennas for 5G and CubeSat applications due to the rapid development of wireless technology and the downsizing of devices and satellites (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can the proposed pixel antenna design achieve miniaturization and high gain? (p. 14); How can pixel patch antennas be designed to meet the functional requirements for 5G and CubeSat applications? (p. 1); What are the performance improvements of the proposed pixel antenna compared to traditional designs? (p. 14); What are the performance metrics and design parameters of pixel patch antennas compared to traditional designs? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: Network analyzer for measuring traditional patch antenna and proposed pixel patch element structures (p. 14)
esp.domain_methodology.performance_metri: Gain, radiation pattern, design area reduction (p. 14)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Finite element method (FEM) and commercial software (Altair FEKO) (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The proposed pixel patch design area reduction is approximately 75%, and the full design area reduction is approximately 90% (p. 14)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers Duroid 6010 (εr = 10.2, tan δ = 0.0023, h = 0.635 mm) (p. 3)

gen.metadata.title: Dual-band optical imaging system-integrated patch antenna based on anisotropic fractal for earth-observation CubeSats
gen.objectives.main_objective: To propose a concept of an S-band patch antenna operating in two bands based on an anisotropic fractal with an optimal method of location for 1U-6U Earth-observation CubeSats (p. 2)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Compare the proposed antenna with existing designs (p. 7); Measure and analyze the performance metrics (p. 7); To integrate the optical (imaging device) and antenna systems into one surface (p. 2); To solve several relevant problems, including increasing the area of solar cells, thereby increasing energy security, simplifying the production of the antenna, and operating the SSC (p. 2); Model and simulate the antenna design (p. 7)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the performance of the antenna in different environmental conditions (p. 8); Investigate the impact of different substrate materials on antenna performance (p. 5); Explore the integration of the proposed antenna with other CubeSat subsystems (p. 5); Explore the integration of the antenna with other subsystems of CubeSats (p. 8)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Optimize the substrate height to improve realized gain and efficiency (p. 5); Use the proposed antenna design for 1U-6U Earth-observation CubeSats (p. 2); Integrate the proposed antenna design in future CubeSat missions (p. 8)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The limited size and communication resources of CubeSat nanosatellites require advanced solutions in this area. Efficient use of the surface area of the CubeSat is also critical. Therefore, optimization of the physical dimensions of SSC components, including antenna devices, is a relevant task (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can the physical dimensions of CubeSat components, including antenna devices, be optimized? (p. 1); What are the characteristics of a dual-band optical imaging system-integrated patch antenna based on an anisotropic fractal for Earth-observation CubeSats? (p. 1); How can a dual-band patch antenna be integrated with an optical imaging system for CubeSats? (p. 7); What are the performance characteristics of the proposed antenna compared to existing designs? (p. 7)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: Vector analyzer MS46121A, RF signal generator NI PXIe-1065, spectrum analyzer Agilent N9340B, rotating stepping system (p. 3)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: HFSS FEM method and QNM package (p. 8)
esp.domain_results.bandwidth: -10 dB impedance bandwidth: 57 MHz (2423–2480 MHz) at 2.45 GHz, 33 MHz (2026–2059 MHz) at 2.04 GHz (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms other designs in terms of compactness and gain (p. 8)
esp.domain_results.gain: 4 dBi at the first resonant frequency, 2.15 dBi at the second resonant frequency (p. 8)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Apple-shaped pattern at 2.45 GHz, more directional characteristics at 2.04 GHz (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.return_loss: Much lower than -10 dB at resonant frequencies (p. 4)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Dual-band patch antenna based on anisotropic fractal (p. 1)

gen.metadata.title: High-gain S-band Patch Antenna System for Earth-observation Cubesat Satellites
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and validate a high-gain, circularly polarized S-band patch antenna system for earth-observing cubesats (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve a compact size and low weight suitable for cubesat standards (p. 1); Ensure good impedance matching and radiation properties (p. 1); Allow for the integration of optical payloads (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Explore the impact of different feeding phase configurations on antenna performance (p. 4)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the designed antenna system for earth-observing cubesats (p. 4); Consider the flexibility of the design for different mission requirements (p. 4)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Designing a high-gain, circularly polarized S-band patch antenna system for earth-observing cubesats, which must comply with size and weight constraints while ensuring good performance (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a high-gain, circularly polarized S-band patch antenna be designed for cubesats? (p. 1); What are the performance metrics of the designed antenna system? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: 9.0 m × 6.0 m × 5.6 m anechoic chamber with TDK IB-011 ferrite tiles and TDK IP-045C pyramidal absorbers (p. 3)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: EM simulations using Microwave Studio by CST (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Unidirectional with a −3 dB aperture of about 58.8° (p. 3)
esp.domain_results.return_loss: −15.05 dB for a single patch, overall system S11 well below −10 dB at 2.45 GHz (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: High-gain circularly polarized S-band patch antenna system (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Four rectangular patches with a 90° phase difference between orthogonal pairs (p. 2)

gen.metadata.title: Microstrip Antenna Gain Enhancement using Multilayer Substrate and Superstrate Structure for Space-Based ADS-B Surveillance
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and optimize a high gain microstrip antenna for CubeSat applications using a multilayer substrate and superstrate structure (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Evaluate the performance of the initial microstrip antenna design (p. 2); Optimize the antenna design by adding a superstrate layer and increasing the substrate thickness (p. 2); Fabricate and measure the performance of the optimized antenna (p. 2); Increase the antenna gain (p. 7); Improve the return loss and bandwidth (p. 7); Maintain a compact form factor (p. 7)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigation of other superstrate designs for further gain improvement (p. 6); Long-term reliability testing of the antenna in space conditions (p. 6); Investigation of other superstrate designs and materials (p. 7)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integration of the antenna into CubeSat systems for real-world testing (p. 6); Further optimization of the antenna design for better performance (p. 6); Further optimization of the antenna design for better performance (p. 7)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for a high gain antenna for space-based ADS-B surveillance to cover remote areas where ground-based systems are insufficient (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What is the impact of using a multilayer substrate and superstrate structure on the antenna's performance? (p. 1); How can the gain and bandwidth of an ADS-B antenna be improved for CubeSat applications? (p. 7); How can the gain of a microstrip antenna be enhanced for CubeSat applications? (p. 1)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms previous works in gain performance (p. 6)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_siz: Fits within the Z-axis side of a 1U CubeSat (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Microstrip patch antenna with superstrate and additional substrate layer (p. 7)
esp.technical_specifications.superstrate: Circular patch identical to the microstrip antenna patch (p. 3)

gen.metadata.title: UWB with Gain Enhancement Archimedean Spiral Microstrip Antennas for On-board Satellite Communications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and evaluate Archimedean spiral microstrip antennas with gain enhancement techniques for ultra-wide band satellite communications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Design a monopole Archimedean spiral microstrip antenna (MASMA) with and without stacked substrate (p. 1); Design a dipole Archimedean spiral microstrip antenna (DASMA) with and without stacked substrate (p. 1); Design a 2x2 array of DASMA with and without stacked substrate (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Conduct experimental validation of the simulation results (p. 2)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use stacked substrate techniques to enhance the performance of spiral microstrip antennas in satellite communications (p. 2)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Traditional spiral antennas for satellite communications have limitations such as reduced gain, radiated power, and increased volume when using absorbing materials (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can the gain and bandwidth of spiral microstrip antennas be enhanced for on-board satellite communications? (p. 1)
esp.domain_results.bandwidth: 6.8 to 24 GHz (MASMA without stacked substrate), 6 to 61 GHz (MASMA with stacked substrate), 7.5 to 24 GHz (DASMA without stacked substrate), 7.5 to 15 GHz (DASMA with stacked substrate), 7.5 to 25 GHz (2x2 array DASMA without stacked substrate), 5.8 to 16 GHz (2x2 array DASMA with stacked substrate) (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The stacked substrate technique significantly enhances the gain and bandwidth of all antenna designs (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.gain: 8 dB increase for MASMA, 10 dB increase for DASMA, 12 dB increase for 2x2 array DASMA (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: FR-4 substrate (εr=4.7, h=0.75mm) and RT 5880 (εr=2.2, h=0.508mm) (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Strip line printed on the substrate surface with a width equal to the spiral arm width (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.frequency_b: 6.8 to 24 GHz (MASMA without stacked substrate), 6 to 61 GHz (MASMA with stacked substrate), 7.5 to 24 GHz (DASMA without stacked substrate), 7.5 to 15 GHz (DASMA with stacked substrate), 7.5 to 25 GHz (2x2 array DASMA without stacked substrate), 5.8 to 16 GHz (2x2 array DASMA with stacked substrate) (p. 2)

gen.metadata.title: Miniaturized and Circularly Polarized Dual-Port Metasurface-Based Leaky-Wave MIMO Antenna for CubeSat Communications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To propose a miniaturized MTS-based leaky-wave MIMO antenna optimized for CubeSat communication systems across microwave and millimeter-wave bands (p. 6)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Operate in three bands (3.75–5.25 GHz, 6.4–15.4 GHz, and 22.5–30 GHz) (p. 1); Support frequency- or phase-dependent beamsteering without mechanical parts (p. 1); Achieve a gain of 12.5 dBi and a radiation efficiency of 85% (p. 1); Achieve high gain, radiation efficiency, and circular polarization (p. 6); Evaluate performance metrics such as gain, bandwidth, and return loss (p. 20); Not mentioned; Support high data rates and beamsteering abilities without electrical or mechanical sophistication (p. 6); Ensure reliable long-distance communication with low power consumption (p. 1); Ensure stable circular polarization (p. 20); Design a compact, dual-port MIMO antenna using a modified phased MTS with coffee bean-shaped arrays (p. 6); Achieve high gain and efficiency (p. 20)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the use of the proposed antenna in multi-satellite networks (p. 11); Investigate the thermal and radiation resilience of the antenna materials (p. 21); Explore the integration of the antenna with other space-constrained platforms such as UAVs and terrestrial IoT systems (p. 21); Study the nonlinear performance and dielectric breakdown behavior for higher power applications (p. 21); Investigate the long-term performance and reliability of the antenna in space conditions (p. 1); Not mentioned; Explore the integration of the antenna with other CubeSat components (p. 1); Explore the impact of different MTS configurations on antenna performance (p. 11)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integrate the antenna into CubeSat communication systems for enhanced performance (p. 1); Integrate the proposed antenna design into CubeSat communication systems (p. 6); Integrate the antenna with onboard energy-harvesting systems or intelligent beam-forming ICs (p. 21); Conduct practical tests to validate simulation results (p. 1); Not mentioned; Conduct experimental validation to confirm simulation results (p. 11); Explore the potential for incorporating this antenna into next-generation CubeSat missions (p. 21)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: CubeSats require lightweight, compact, high-performance antennas that meet strict size, weight, and power (SWaP) constraints while sustaining solid performance in severe space conditions (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a miniaturized MTS-based leaky-wave MIMO antenna be designed for CubeSat communication systems? (p. 6); What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna in CubeSat applications? (p. 20); Not mentioned; How can a metasurface-based leaky-wave MIMO antenna be designed to meet CubeSat communication requirements? (p. 1); What are the performance metrics and benefits of the proposed antenna design? (p. 6); What are the key performance metrics and design features that enhance the antenna's efficiency and reliability? (p. 1); How can a miniaturized antenna achieve high gain and efficiency while maintaining stable circular polarization? (p. 20)
esp.domain_methodology.performance_metri: ['Gain', 'Bandwidth', 'Return Loss', 'VSWR', 'Radiation Pattern', 'Radiation Efficiency', 'Axial Ratio', 'Sidelobe Level'] (p. 14, p. 18)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Full-wave simulation using CST Microwave Studio (or HFSS) (p. 18)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms previous studies in terms of compactness, frequency coverage, gain, and multifunctionality (p. 18)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Bidirectional at lower bands and more directional at higher bands (p. 16)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_siz: Fits within the standard 10 × 10 × 10 cm³ CubeSat unit (p. 6)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Miniaturized circular polarized dual-port MTS-based leaky-wave MIMO antenna (p. 20)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers RT 5880 (εr = 2.1, tan δ = 0.001, h = 1.5 mm) (p. 11)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Rectangular patch connected to a transmission line (p. 7)

gen.metadata.title: Optimized Design and Multiphysics Analysis of a Ka-Band Stacked Antenna for CubeSat Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and optimize a Ka-band stacked patch antenna for CubeSat applications, and to analyze its thermal and mechanical performance (p. 4)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Perform a multiphysics thermal and mechanical analysis to ensure operational stability (p. 1); Optimize the antenna geometry using a PSO algorithm (p. 8); Achieve a wideband operation and high gain (p. 1); Optimize the antenna design using Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) to achieve maximum bandwidth and return loss (p. 4); Conduct thermal and mechanical analysis to ensure the antenna can withstand the environmental conditions of a LEO mission (p. 7); Perform thermal and mechanical analysis of the antenna in a LEO environment (p. 8); Not mentioned; Evaluate the antenna performance in terms of bandwidth, gain, and radiation pattern (p. 8)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Explore the use of other materials and configurations for further optimization (p. 1); Investigate the performance of the antenna in different orbital environments (p. 1); Investigate the use of other epoxy resins capable of reaching high tensile, shear, and flexural stresses (p. 12); Not mentioned; Explore the optimization of other antenna types for CubeSat applications (p. 8); Investigate the impact of different orbits and mission profiles on antenna performance (p. 8)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the optimized design for future CubeSat missions (p. 1); Use mechanically performing resins or adaptive temperature control strategies to manage thermal and mechanical stresses (p. 12); Conduct further thermal and mechanical testing to validate the simulation results (p. 8); Not mentioned; Implement the optimized antenna design in CubeSat missions (p. 8); Perform similar multiphysics analyses for other CubeSat components (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need to optimize the design of a Ka-band stacked patch antenna for CubeSat applications, considering the unique environmental and thermal conditions of space (p. 4)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a Ka-band stacked patch antenna be designed to meet the multiphysics constraints of CubeSat missions? (p. 1); How can a stacked patch antenna be optimized for CubeSat applications in the Ka-band? (p. 8); What are the thermal and mechanical performance characteristics of the optimized antenna in a LEO environment? (p. 8); How can the antenna design be optimized to meet the operational requirements in Ka-band for CubeSat applications? (p. 4); Not mentioned; What is the impact of thermal and mechanical stresses on the performance of the antenna? (p. 1); What are the thermal and mechanical stresses that the antenna will experience in a LEO mission, and how can they be mitigated? (p. 7)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm, finite difference time domain (FDTD) simulations, and heat transfer analysis (pp. 4-7)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms other designs in bandwidth and gain (p. 10)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Broadside radiation with stable gain over frequency (p. 10)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers RT/duroid 5880 (εr = 2.2, tan δ = 0.001, h = 0.254 mm) (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Single feed point centered on an axis and shifted towards the orthogonal edge (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.frequency_b: Ka-band (26–34.7 GHz for down- and uplink) (p. 1)
